definitions: show reverence and adoration for a deity through prayer ceremonies or religious practices
regard with great respect admiration or devotion often to an excessive degree
examples: Many people worship at the local church every Sunday morning
Ancient civilizations would worship their gods through elaborate temple rituals
Teenagers often worship their favorite celebrities and follow their every move
She worships her grandmother who raised her with love and wisdom

definitions: defeat someone thoroughly in a competition fight or argument
examples: The home team worsted their rivals in the championship game
She worsted him in the debate with her well-researched arguments

definitions: impress someone greatly causing amazement admiration or enthusiasm
examples: The magician's incredible tricks wowed the entire audience last night
Her presentation skills really wowed the hiring committee during interviews

definitions: cause something harmful damaging or destructive to happen especially in a violent way
examples: The hurricane wreaked havoc on the coastal communities last summer
His reckless decisions wreaked chaos in the company's financial department

definitions: destroy or severely damage something through impact collision or violent action
spoil or ruin something completely making it unusable or unsuccessful
examples: The storm wrecked several boats anchored in the harbor
He wrecked his car when he lost control on the icy road
Poor planning completely wrecked our vacation to the mountains
Don't let one bad grade wreck your confidence in mathematics

definitions: pull or twist something suddenly and violently away from its position
injure a joint or muscle by twisting it suddenly and painfully
examples: She wrenched the door open despite the rusty hinges
The child wrenched the toy from his sister's hands
He wrenched his ankle while playing basketball last week
Be careful not to wrench your back lifting heavy boxes

definitions: forcibly pull something from a person's grasp or take control with effort
examples: The security guard wrested the weapon from the intruder's hand
They finally wrested control of the company from corrupt management

definitions: engage in a fight or contest involving grappling and trying to throw opponent down
struggle with a difficult problem task or decision requiring great effort
examples: The two boys wrestled playfully on the living room carpet
Professional wrestlers train for years to wrestle safely in competitions
She wrestled with the decision to move across the country
Scientists wrestle with complex equations to solve climate change problems

definitions: make or cause lines folds or creases to appear on a surface especially fabric or skin
examples: Don't sit too long or you'll wrinkle your dress shirt
She wrinkled her nose at the unpleasant smell from the garbage

definitions: make a photocopy of a document using a photocopying machine
examples: Please xerox these reports for everyone attending the meeting
I need to xerox my passport before traveling abroad tomorrow

definitions: sail or cruise in a yacht especially for pleasure or sport
examples: They love to yacht around the Mediterranean during summer vacations
Wealthy executives often yacht between Caribbean islands for business meetings

definitions: talk persistently or chatter about trivial matters in an annoying way
examples: My neighbors yak on the phone for hours every evening
Stop yakking and let's focus on finishing this project today

definitions: pull something with a sudden sharp forceful movement
examples: She yanked the cord to start the old lawn mower
Don't yank on the dog's leash when he stops walking

definitions: give a sharp shrill bark especially of small dogs or talk continuously
examples: The little terrier yaps whenever someone walks past the house
Those small dogs yap at everything that moves in the yard

definitions: tell long rambling stories especially ones that are implausible or exaggerated
examples: Grandpa loves to yarn about his adventures as a young sailor
The fishermen yarned about their catches growing bigger each time

definitions: move unsteadily off course especially of ships or aircraft deviating from intended direction
examples: The ship began to yaw dangerously in the rough seas
Strong crosswinds caused the small plane to yaw during landing

definitions: give a short sharp cry especially of pain fear or surprise
examples: The puppy yelped when someone accidentally stepped on its tail
She yelped in surprise when the cold water hit her skin

definitions: have a strong desire or craving for something
examples: After months abroad she yens for her mother's home cooking
He's been yenning to visit Japan since studying the language

definitions: give a short sharp cry or bark especially expressing excitement or pain
examples: The excited puppy yipped when its owner came home from work
Coyotes yip and howl in the desert at night

definitions: sing with rapid changes between normal chest voice and high falsetto
examples: Swiss mountain herders traditionally yodel to communicate across valleys
She learned to yodel while visiting her relatives in Austria

definitions: join or link two things or people together especially in partnership or servitude
examples: Farmers yoke oxen together to pull heavy plows through fields
The business partners yoked their resources to start the company

definitions: strike suddenly with electricity laser or similar energy causing damage or destruction
destroy eliminate or kill something quickly and decisively
examples: Lightning zapped the old oak tree during yesterday's thunderstorm
The bug zapper zaps mosquitoes with an electric current
Use this spray to zap weeds in your garden beds
The new medication can zap infections within just two days

definitions: aim or focus precisely on a target objective or specific point
reduce something to nothing or eliminate it completely
examples: The sniper zeroed his rifle scope on the distant target
Scientists zeroed their instruments on the newly discovered star
The company plans to zero their carbon emissions by next year
We need to zero the account balance before closing it

definitions: add enthusiasm energy or excitement to make something more interesting or enjoyable
examples: Fresh herbs really zest up this simple pasta dish beautifully
Her lively personality zests every party she attends with joy

definitions: move forward in a pattern of sharp angles alternating left and right
examples: The skier zigzagged down the steep mountain slope with skill
The rabbit zigzagged across the field to escape the fox

definitions: fasten or close something using a zipper fastening device
move very quickly with energy or make a sharp whizzing sound
examples: Remember to zip your jacket before going out in the cold
She zipped her backpack after putting her books inside
The motorcycle zipped past us on the highway at high speed
Time seems to zip by when you're having fun with friends

definitions: fasten or close something using a zipper fastening device
examples: Please zipper your sleeping bag to stay warm tonight
The dress zippers up the back making it hard to reach

definitions: move or travel very quickly especially with a buzzing or humming sound
change the magnification of a camera lens to make image appear closer or farther
examples: Race cars zoom around the track at incredible speeds
The kids zoomed down the hill on their new bicycles
Zoom in on the bird's nest to see the baby birds
The photographer zoomed out to capture the entire landscape

definitions: express pleasure relief satisfaction or understanding with a vocal sound
examples: The crowd aahed when the fireworks lit up the night sky
She aahed with relief after finally solving the difficult puzzle

definitions: become less intense severe or widespread gradually diminishing in force or amount
examples: The storm finally abated after three days of heavy rain
Her anger slowly abated as she listened to his sincere apology

definitions: formally give up power position or responsibility especially of a monarch renouncing throne
examples: The king decided to abdicate in favor of his eldest son
She abdicated her role as CEO to pursue humanitarian work

definitions: take someone away illegally by force or deception typically for ransom or harm
examples: The criminals planned to abduct the wealthy businessman's daughter
Aliens abduct humans in many popular science fiction movies

definitions: encourage or help someone to do something wrong or illegal especially a crime
examples: He was charged with abetting the thieves by driving their getaway car
Don't abet her bad behavior by making excuses for her actions

definitions: accept or tolerate something unpleasant or difficult without complaint
follow or keep to rules agreements or decisions obediently
examples: I cannot abide rudeness in my classroom under any circumstances
She couldn't abide the noise from the construction site anymore
All students must abide by the school's code of conduct
Citizens are expected to abide by the laws of their country

definitions: formally put an end to a system practice or institution especially by law
examples: Many countries have abolished capital punishment in recent decades
The new government promised to abolish unfair tax laws immediately

definitions: stop or abandon a process action or plan before it is completed
end a pregnancy deliberately before the fetus can survive independently
examples: Mission control decided to abort the space launch due to bad weather
The pilot had to abort the landing and circle the airport again
The doctor explained all options including the decision to abort
Medical complications sometimes require difficult decisions about pregnancy

definitions: exist in large numbers or amounts being plentiful or widespread
examples: Wildlife abounds in this protected national forest reserve
Opportunities abound for those willing to work hard and persevere

definitions: remove or keep oneself away from a place or situation deliberately
examples: He chose to absent himself from the controversial meeting yesterday
Students who absent themselves frequently may face academic consequences

definitions: declare someone free from guilt blame or responsibility for wrongdoing
examples: The judge absolved her of all charges due to lack of evidence
The priest absolved him of his sins during the confession

definitions: restrain oneself from doing or enjoying something especially as a matter of principle
examples: Many people abstain from alcohol for health or religious reasons
Several council members abstained from voting on the controversial proposal

definitions: agree to a demand request or treaty often reluctantly or after pressure
assume an important position or office especially becoming monarch
examples: The company finally acceded to the workers' demands for better pay
After long negotiations both countries acceded to the peace treaty
Prince Charles will accede to the throne after Queen Elizabeth
She acceded to the presidency after winning the election

definitions: increase speed velocity or rate of movement of something
cause something to happen sooner or develop more quickly than normal
examples: The driver accelerated to merge onto the busy highway safely
The rocket accelerates rapidly after leaving the launch pad
New technology helps accelerate the learning process for students
The company plans to accelerate production to meet holiday demand

definitions: make something more noticeable prominent or emphasized to draw attention to it
examples: Dark eyeliner accentuates her beautiful green eyes perfectly
His accent actually accentuates the humor in his storytelling

definitions: record the addition of new items to a collection library or inventory
examples: The librarian will accession all donated books into the catalog system
Museums carefully accession each artifact with detailed documentation

definitions: praise someone or something enthusiastically and publicly with great approval
examples: Critics acclaim her latest novel as a literary masterpiece
The audience acclaimed the young pianist with thunderous applause

definitions: give or grant someone power status or recognition formally or officially
examples: The university accorded her an honorary degree for her contributions
The treaty accords both nations equal trading rights

definitions: accumulate or receive payments benefits or advantages gradually over a period of time
examples: Interest accrues daily on your savings account balance
Employees accrue vacation days based on their years of service

definitions: gather or collect things gradually over time increasing in quantity or number
examples: Dust accumulates quickly on furniture in this dry climate
She accumulated a fortune through wise investments over many years

definitions: achieve complete success in something especially a test or challenging task brilliantly
examples: She aced her final chemistry exam with a perfect score
He hopes to ace the job interview with thorough preparation

definitions: feel a continuous dull pain in a part of the body
feel intense sadness or yearning for someone or something absent
examples: My muscles ache after yesterday's intense workout at the gym
Her tooth ached so badly she couldn't sleep all night
His heart aches for his homeland after years of exile
Parents often ache to see their children who live far away
